properties.ariaLabel: should i buy this thing or no permalink

children.value: Should I Buy This Thing? Or No?

Whenever I'm considering a new purchase, I try to figure out a way to make the cost more tangible so I can determine whether or not it’s worth it. In high school and college I used to think of the opportunity cost in terms of the other things I would likely buy with the money instead.

It was usually food that resonated the most with my primordial brain. When I was really young it was candy bars, then it was Hot and Spicky McChickens* from McDonalds and most recently, Chipotle burritos. For instance, how many Chipotle burritos is this diamond ring going to cost me? 125? That’s a lot of burritos... maybe I’d rather have the burritos instead of getting married. It was a good system.
After I graduated and got a real job, I started investing any money that I didn’t spend each month.

Pretty great, huh? Sure… but this completely ruined my previous opportunity cost strategy. Making a purchase didn’t equate to losing X burritos; instead, it just came out of the money that I would have invested at the end of the month. Having X less shares of an S&P 500 index just doesn't have the same ring, it's not nearly as visceral.

properties.ariaLabel: aligning your metaphorical left and right side brains permalink

children.value: Aligning Your Metaphorical Left and Right Side Brains

In reality, forgoing investment for consumption is actually a much bigger deal. If invested money grows steadily over time and I have a fairly long time horizon, I could be losing out on way more than a few burritos just by buying this thing.

But how much? Are we talking fancy cars or mansions or college savings for my kid(s)? Is that slice of pizza really worth not being able to hire a professional chef for the last 30 years of my life? Hyperbole, sure, (unless that's a really expensive slice of pizza) but without a better way to conceptualize the cost, how can we know how hyperbolic it is?

Time for a new strategy. Instead of things, let's focus on something else that's easy to conceptualize: time. Time to financial independence, to be specific. We'll define "financial independence" as the point at which one can live indefinitely off of investment income only. It won’t matter if you live for 6 more years or 600 more years.

What will I do after financial independence? Quit my job, if I feel like it. Probably a lot of dad duties. I can spend time tinkering with pet projects, building Hogwarts in Minecraft, or doing whatever I feel like I want to do, gosh. So that’s the big question:
if instead of buying this thing, I invest the money, how much earlier, on average, will I reach financial independence?

properties.ariaLabel: should i buy this or no permalink

children.value: Should I buy this? or no?
Here are a set of financial attributes for the average U.S. household (data from 2016), how much is buying this thing going to delay my their FI?
Yearly Savings: Savings rate * Median Salary =
Here's how buying things would delay the average American's financial independence:
new car you've been eyeing? -- 11 years 155 days 23 hours 53 minutes and 48 second
$5,000 Trip to Europe? -- 1 years 32 days 18 hours 28 minutes and 55 seconds
$15 Lunch? -- 1 days 3 hours 36 minutes and 43 seconds
$1.95 Guac on your burrito? -- 3 hours 40 minutes and 53 seconds

properties.ariaLabel: how does your situation stack up permalink

children.value: How does your situation stack up?
This will help you conceptualize how much you are giving up when making a purchase. Then you can decide if it's worth it!

How much money do you need to reach financial independence? Here is one common way to think about it:
To calculate how much wealth you need to accumulate, with some assumptions that we'll detail in a moment, it only takes two steps:
Determine your annual expenses (food, rent/mortgage, fun things, child care, etc.). One assumption is that you will continue to spend this much every year in retirement.
Multiply the number you calculated in (1) by 25. This is a guideline for how much you need.
That’s it. If you spend $40,000 per year, you'll need to save and invest $1,000,000 before you are financially independent.

Where did that “25” number come from? That corresponds to a safe withdrawal rate (SWR) of 4%. SWR is a retirement philosophy, that can also be applied to financial independence as well. That you can withdraw a fixed (but inflation adjusted) amount from your investments every year and your investment income (growth, dividends, interest, etc.) will keep the account in the black.

properties.ariaLabel: why not a higher swr permalink

children.value: Over the long term, a portfolio of 100% stocks has historically returned an annualized inflation adjusted return of

. So if you only withdraw 4% of those earnings per year, your portfolio should increase 3% each year. So why not a 7% SWR? The issue is that those returns don't come in gradually and consistently, they come in spurts with a lot volatility in between. Poor returns in early phases of financial independence are particularly bad. There is a chance that the day you reach your financial independence wealth goal the market crashes 20% more. A nest egg 20% smaller will grow significantly slower than the original amount, which puts the whole account at risk of being drained if the withdrawal rate is too high. This is referred to as sequence of return risk.
A SWR of 4% was determined by researchers evaluating the optimal SWR that would keep a portfolio ballance above 0 after a 30 year period even after weathering the
worst possible historical sequence of returns

properties.ariaLabel: why not a lower swr permalink

children.value: A quick Google search will show plenty of detractors from the 4% rule. They argue it should be lower for a variety or reasons (slower economic growth, lower interest rates, etc..).

One of the key themes here is that it's very difficult to be 100% certain of anything. In this case, the additional wealth needed to gain a marginal point of certainty is high. The good news is, depending on your philosophy and situation, being 100% certain isn't necessary.

If you happen to get very unlucky and reach financial independence at the beginning of one of the worst historical periods for growth, you likely have options. The 4% rule is very rigid and assumes constant withdrawals of a fixed (inflation-adjusted) amount each year from your portfolio regardless of market conditions. A little flexibility to decrease spending or a willingness generate even just a little income during periods of slow growth can go a long way to ensuring portfolio longevity.
This tool uses a SWR of 4% by default. You can make it higher or lower under the 'assumptions' expander. Here are some other interesting takes on SWR:
About the original research for the 4% rule
Adjustable SWE for early retirees (longer than 30 years), depending on market valuations.
Only government bond portfolio in a low interest rate environment.
Historical SWR by allocation and country

The default assumptions for the calculator is a portfolio of 100% stocks with historic return rates. If this doesn't match your situation or expectations, feel free to adjust the sliders in the assumptions accordion. Changing the SWR slider changes how much wealth you'll need to accumulate to reach FI. Changing the ROI slider affects the how much every dollar you spend increases the amount of time required to reach that wealth goal.

Based on the default assumptions, if you spend $35,000 (2020 dollars) per year, you need $875,000 (2020 dollars) to reach FI. You can withdraw $35,000 (2020 dollars), or 4% of the $875,000, per year and expect that you will accrue interest/dividends/capital gains fast enough that this account will replenish itself indefinitely. In other words, the value of the account, will not decrease over time despite consistent withdrawals.

You may or may not be tempted by the 39 seconds you gain by picking up a penny off the ground and investing it, or from the 16 minutes and 9 seconds you get from doing the same with a quarter. Clearly some things are worth the cost, but you now have a better idea of what you're giving up.

Late one night in New Hampshire I just got off of a flight from Denver and was starving. I busted into the closest McDonald's I could find and boldly declared "Two Hot 'n Spicys, please!". The very Bostonian man behind the counter looked up at me, perplexed, and said "Two what?". "Hot n Spicys?" I said, much less confidently. I looked up at the menu and to my horror, in the place of the Hot n' Spicy on the Dollar Menu was just the word "McChicken". "Ummm... two McChickens". So I ate the two bland chicken sandwiches.. meh. I learned later that the Hot n’ Spicy McChicken is a regional delicacy those who don't live in certain parts of the south and southwestern United States will have to travel to appreciate. This is what you're missing out on
